importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous government shutdown that lasted 35 days, making it the longest in history and resulting in significant economic loss.
The end date of the longest government shutdown in history, marking the conclusion of a 35-day period that cost an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The date of the latest update on the current government shutdown, indicating ongoing political deadlock and lack of funding resolution.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the longest government shutdown in U.S. history, which had significant economic and operational impacts on federal agencies.
The current full government shutdown, which began without a resolution to the 12 appropriations bills, affecting all federal operations.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown, lasting from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, was the longest in nearly 50 years and cost the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The current shutdown is a full government shutdown, unlike the 2018 event, which was partial, with only some agencies operating.
The 2018 shutdown resulted in approximately 800,000 federal employees being affected, with about 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay but required to report to work.
The current Congress has failed to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills to fund the federal government.
Government shutdowns have become less frequent since 1990, but recent political polarization and procedural barriers like the Senate filibuster have prolonged legislative delays.
Republican Speaker Mike Johnson oversees a narrow House majority, and without 60 Senate votes, the GOP lacks the power to overcome a filibuster, complicating negotiations to reopen the government.

namedEntities.name: Gillian Roberts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is one of the reporters contributing to the article, providing authoritative coverage of the government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Kaanita Iyer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a co-author of the article, contributing to the reporting and context of the current government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the source of the article and provides public updates on government shutdowns and political developments.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided an estimate of $3 billion in lost GDP due to the 2018 shutdown, offering economic context to the impact of government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the Republican Speaker of the House, overseeing a narrow majority, which makes legislative action difficult and contributes to the current shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a procedural barrier that prevents the GOP from passing spending bills, contributing to the inability to resolve the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: US federal government
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central subject of the article, as it is currently in a full shutdown due to lack of funding.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to pass these bills is the direct cause of the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The start date of the longest government shutdown in history, marking a key point in the history of federal funding lapses.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The end date of the longest government shutdown in history, indicating the duration and conclusion of a major fiscal crisis.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article reports on the ongoing full government shutdown in the United States, highlighting that the most recent shutdown—starting on December 22, 2018, and ending on January 25, 2019—was the longest in nearly 50 years and cost an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. The 2018 shutdown was partial, affecting about 800,000 employees, with 300,000 furloughed and others exempted. In contrast, the current shutdown is a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. Political factors, such as the narrow Republican majority in the House and the Senate filibuster, have made bipartisan negotiations difficult. The article underscores how political polarization and procedural barriers contribute to prolonged government shutdowns, impacting federal operations and public services.
title: The US Government Shutdown: A Timeline of the Longest Shutdown in Nearly 50 Years
